bibl.title: ‘An organic affection’ (‘An organic affection, or, An affection of the heart’), farce in one act by Mrs. Alfred Philips.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 January for performance at the Royal Olympic 12 January 1852. Signed by W. Farren. Includes performances of a number of songs, one of which contains the phrase ‘affection of the heart.’ LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the word ‘damn’ be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A duel in the dark’, farce in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 January for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 14 January 1852. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the word ‘damn’ be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Matrimonial—A Gentleman, etc. For further particulars apply at—The Royal Olympic Theatre’, farce in one act by J. V. Bridgeman.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 February for performance at the Olympic 12 February 1852. Signed by W. Farren. Stage directions underlined.

bibl.title: ‘A matrimonial prospectus’, farce in one act by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 February for performance at the Strand 4 March 1852.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Matrimonial prospectuses in Lacy‘s, vol. 6, no. 81.

bibl.title: ‘No. 3 Fig Tree Court, Temple, or, Us and our clerks’, farce in one act by ‘John Roakes’ (i.e., Tom Taylor).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 February for performance at the Princess’s 6 March 1852.

bibl.title: ‘The Corsican brothers’, drama in three acts. Printed (Lacy’s, vol. 6, no. 79).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 March 1852 for performance at the Marylebone. Scrap of a playbill that lists title and ‘stage manager copy’ bound in with text. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that exclamations such as ‘Oh Lord’ and ‘Good Lord’ be omitted. For other versions see Add. 43037 H, 52930 P, 52930 S, 52930 Y, and 52931 G. For burlesqued versions see 52931 I and 52931 L.

bibl.title: ‘Wittikind and his brothers, or, The seven swan princes and the fair Melusine’ (‘The swan princes’), fairy tale in two acts, by ‘John Roakes’ (i.e. Tom Taylor).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 March for performance at the Princess’s 12 April 1852. Extensive revisions throughout text. Some notes about types of music to be used.

bibl.title: ‘The Corsican brothers, or, Les frères Corses’, ‘dramatic romance’ in three acts and five tableaux, adapted ‘from the romance of M. Dumas by MM. E. Grangé and X. de Montépin’. Printed (Lacy’s Acting Edition, vol. 6, no. 79).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 April for performance at the Queen’s Theatre, Dublin, 12 April 1852. Actors’ names listed alongside dramatis personae. Text includes descriptions of costumes. Advertising on front and back covers. For other versions see Add. 43037 H, 52930 P, 52930 S, 52930 Y, and 52930 Z. For burlesqued versions see Add. 52931 I and 52931 L.

bibl.title: ‘Mephistopheles, or, An ambassador from below’, an extravaganza in one act by R. B. Brough and H. S. Edwards.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 10 April for performance at the Adelphi 12 April 1852. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Songs included in MS. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 does not appear to record this play.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 25, no. 361. A burlesque of the same title by an unnamed author was licensed in 1894 (Add. 53560 D).

bibl.title: ‘A chain of events’, drama in eight acts by ‘Slingsby Lawrence’ (i.e. G. H. Lewes) and C. J. Matthews.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 April for performance at the Lyceum 12 April 1852. The whole of Act II is devoted to scenic effect with no dialogue at all. Songs included with MS. For another version, see ‘The queen of the market’, Add. 52931 K.

bibl.title: ‘The lost husband’, drama in two acts, adapted from the French by Charles Reade.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 April for performance at the Strand 26 April 1852. Title page lists W. R. Copeland as lessee. Small number of revisions, usually in pencil.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 6, no. 86. There were two other licensed plays under the same title; a farce performed at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket in 1862 (Add. 53015 T), and an operetta privately performed in London and Brighton in 1884 and 1885, and licensed for performance at the Opera Comique in 1886 (Add. 53357 C).

bibl.title: ‘Ganem, the slave of love’, burlesque in one act by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 May for performance at the Royal Olympic 31 May 1852. ‘H. Farren for W. Farren’ is listed on title page. MS includes songs.

bibl.title: ‘Taking by storm’, farce in one act by‘Frank Churchill' [i.e. G. H. Lewes].
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 June for performance at the Lyceum 5 June 1852.

bibl.title: ‘A novel expedient’, farce in one act by B. N. Webster.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 June for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 26 June 1852. Request for licence unsigned, but apparently in the author’s hand, as is part of the text itself. Performed as ‘Book the third, chapter the first’, at the Court Theatre, 12 June 1857 (Add. 52967 U).
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 7, no. 97. For a French version, Livre III, chapitre 1er, by E. Pierron and A, Laferrière, see Add. 52938 N.

bibl.title: ‘Sink or swim’, a drama in two acts by Thomas Morton, Jr.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 July for performance at the Royal Olympic 2 August 1852. Signed by manager, W. Farren. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that a few words be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The writing on the wall’, drama in three acts by J. M. Morton and Thomas Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 July for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 2 August 1852. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Extensive revisions in various hands (not the work of the Examiner of Plays) appear throughout text. Various different types of paper used. Large numbers and prompts such as ‘call’ pencilled in throughout text.

bibl.title: ‘Anne Blake’, drama in five acts by J. W. Marston. Printed (C. Marshall, 1852).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 August 1852 for performance at the Princess’s 28 October 1852. Text written in two different hands.

bibl.title: ‘The master passion’, comedy in two acts by Mrs. Alfred Philips.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 August for performance at the Olympic 1 September 1852. Title page is signed by W. Farren, manager. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that duelling scene in first act be omitted and that a phrase containing the word ‘God’ be substituted. Other revisions not the work of the Examiner of Plays appear throughout text.

bibl.title: ‘Wanted. 1,000 spirited young milliners for the gold diggings’, farce in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 October 1852 for performance the same day at the Olympic. ‘Willm Farren, Manager’ appears on title page. Revisions not the work of the Examiner of Plays appear throughout text.

bibl.title: ‘Box and Cox married and settled’, farce in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 October for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 12 October 1852. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Sarah Blangi’ (‘Sarah the Creole’), drama in five acts by Morris Barnett.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 October for performance at the Olympic 18 October 1852. Title page lists ‘Will Farren, Manager.’ Dramatis personae lists actors’ names including ‘Farren’. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the word ‘God’ be substituted. Revisions not the work of the Examiner of Plays appear throughout the work.

bibl.title: ‘The mysterious lady’ (‘Wealth makes the man’), altered from ‘The Fitzapes’, drama in two acts by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 October for performance at the Lyceum 18 October 1852.

bibl.title: ‘A house out of windows’, farce in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 October for performance at the Lyceum 18 October 1852. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Civilization', a play in five acts by John H. Wilkins.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 October for performance at the City of London Theatre 10 November 1852. Signed Mssrs. Johnson and Nelson Lee. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the expressions 'Lord' and 'O Lord' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The woman I adore’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 October 1852 for performance the same day at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions not the work of the Examiner of Plays appear throughout text. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the word 'Damn' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A capital match’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, 4 November 1852. Names of actors included alongside dramatis personae. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions throughout. Stage directions pencilled in throughout. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Gotobed Tom’, farce in one act by Thomas Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 November for performance at the Olympic 25 November 1852. Cover signed by Will Farren, Manager. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A phenomenon in a smock frock’, farce in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 10 December for performance at the Lyceum 15 December 1852. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Leo the terrible, a fable for the present day’, burlesque.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 December for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, 27 December 1852. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Written in a number of different hands and on a number of different papers. Revisions throughout the text.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 9, no. 126, where it is attributed to J. S. Coyne and F. Talfourd.

bibl.title: ‘Harlequin Studibras, or, Dame Durden and the droll days of the Merry Monarch', pantomime. Licence sent 20 December 1852 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that ‘The lines, 'Proclamation—bearbaiting! This act is not
bibl.licence: Licence d by the Lord Chamberlain’ be omitted from the text.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 9, no. 122, where the play is attributed to E. L. Blanchard.

bibl.title: ‘The good woman in the wood’, Christmas piece in two acts by J. R. Planché, based on Mlle. de la Force’s fairy tale La bonne femme..
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 December for performance at the Lyceum 27 December 1852. Songs sent separately make up first eight pages of the MS.

bibl.title: ‘Gold’, drama in five acts, by Charles Reade.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 January for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 10 January 1853. Plays of the same title were performed in 1851 and 1880.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 11, no. 152, and in Dick’s Standard Plays, no. 1053, in 1896.

bibl.title: ‘Lilian Gervais’ (altered from ‘Lilian Rene’ al.‘The pearl of Normandy'), drama in three acts by Morris Barnett.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 January for performance at the Olympic 17 January 1853. Signed by W. Farren, manager. Revisions throughout. Signed by Morris Barnett on back cover.

bibl.title: ‘Louis XI’, a ‘grand melodramatic play’ in three acts by W. R. Markwell.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 January for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 14 February 1853. Signed by E. J. Smith.

bibl.title: ‘The obstinate family', farce in one act, adapted from a German original by S. Phelps the younger.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 February for performance at Sadlers Wells 19 February 1853.

bibl.title: ‘Marco Spada’, drama in three acts.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 March for performance at the Princess’s 28 March 1853. Written in different hands. For other versions see Add. 52938 Z, 52939 D and 52940 D.

bibl.title: ‘Mr Buckstone's ascent of Mount Parnassus’, burlesque prelude in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 March for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 28 March 1853. Request for licence signed by J. B. Buckstone. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘A strange history’, in nine acts by 'Slingsby Lawrence' (i.e. G. H. Lewes).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 March for performance at the Lyceum 28 March 1853. Revisions on separate sheets of paper attached to some of the pages.

bibl.title: ‘The Egyptian’, play in five acts by John H. Wilkins.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 March for performance at the City of London 4 April 1853. Signed by Messrs. Johnson and Nelson Lee.

bibl.title: ‘Elopements in high life’, comedy in five acts by Robert Sullivan.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 April for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 7 April 1853. Request for licence written and signed by J. Baldwin Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘Honour among thieves, or, A desperate game’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 April for performance at the Adelphi 7 April 1853. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. 'A marvellous, pleasant love story' as well as actors’ names written in pencil alongside dramatis personae. Detailed stage directions.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 10, no. 144, under the title A desperate game.

bibl.title: ‘Love's disguises’, domestic drama in two acts by H. H. Paul.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 April for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 13 April 1853.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's (vol. 11, no. 153) under the title The mob cap.

bibl.title: ‘Uncle Crotchet’, a farce in one act by Mrs. Alfred Phillips.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 April for performance at the Olympic 18 April 1853. Signed by manager, W. Farren.

bibl.title: ‘A.S.S.', a farce in one act by J. M. Maddox.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 April for performance at the Lyceum 23 April 1853.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 10, no. 148. For another version, under the title ‘A. H., my daughter’s intended’, see Add. 52935 N.

bibl.title: ‘A fast train! High pressure!! Express!!!', farce in one act by John Medex Maddox.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 April for performance at the Lyceum 29 April 1853. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that 'Lord' be substituted with 'Heaven.'
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 10, no. 149, with the additional subtitle 'A short trip'.

bibl.title: ‘The miller of Derwent Water’, an original drama in three acts by Edward Fitzball. Imperfect, lacking Act III.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 April for performance at the Olympic 2 May 1853. Signed by W. Farren. ‘57 Warren Street, Fitzroy Square’ listed on cover of each act. Actors‘ names listed alongside dramatis personae. Revisions throughout. Stage directions pencilled in. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that requires that 'God' be substituted with 'Heaven.'

bibl.title: ‘Trying it on‘ ('An enquiring mind' al. 'Who stole the diamonds?'), a farce by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 April for performance at the Lyceum 5 May 1853. For French versions see Add. 52937 T and 52938 J.

bibl.title: ‘The lawyers', comedy in three acts by 'Slingsby Lawrence' (i.e., George Henry Lewes).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 May for performance at the Lyceum 23 May 1853.

bibl.title: ‘Marcretti, or, The brigand's sacrifice' (altered from ‘Marco Spada’), romantic drama in three acts by John Kingdom, from the French by E. Scribe.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 May for performance 31 May 1853. Title page signed. For other versions see Add. 52938 S, 52938 Z and 52939 D.

bibl.title: ‘Rappings and table movings', farce in one act by Howard M. Paul.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 June for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 16 June 1853. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘Chesterfield Thinskin', a farce in one act by J. M. Maddox.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 June for performance at the Princess’s 20 July 1853. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the words 'God' and 'damn' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The camp at Chobham', farce in one act by Mark Lemon.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 June for performance at the Adelphi 30 June 1853. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, supplementary vol. 3, and Webster’s, vol. 17.

bibl.title: ‘The merchant of Venice preserved' ('Shylock, a Jerusalem hearty-joke'), burlesque in one act.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 July for performance at the Olympic 4 July 1853. Signed by W. Farren, manager. Revisions throughout. Songs included in MS.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 11, no. 159, and there attributed to F. Talfourd.

bibl.title: ‘The Times', drama in three acts by 'John Daly' (i.e. John Daly Besemeres).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 July for performance at the Olympic 18 July 1853. Signed by W. Farren. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the words 'Lord' and 'God' be substituted with 'Heaven'.

bibl.title: ‘Going to Chobham, or, The petticoat captains', farce in one act by C. H. Hazlewood.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 July for performance at the City of London 30 July 1853. Signed by Austin Lee.

bibl.title: ‘The fountain of beauty, or, The king, the princess and the genie', a fancy extravaganza in two acts by J. M. Kingdom.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 August for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 5 September 1853. Signed by C. F. Smith. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Plot and passion' ('Mine and countermine'), drama in three acts by 'John Roakes' (i.e., Tom Taylor) and John Lang.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 September for performance at the Olympic 17 October 1853. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘The camp at the Olympic', burletta in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 October for performance at the Olympic 17 October 1853.

bibl.title: ‘Hotel charges, or, How to cook a biffin', farcical sketch in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 October for performance at the Adelphi 10 October 1853. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘The Lancers, or, The gentleman's son', drama in three acts by Capt. Leicester Vernon.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 October for performance at the Princess’s 1 November 1853. Stage directions and speaking cues underlined in red. Almost certainly based on Un fils de famille, by J. F. A. Bayard and C. H. E. E. Desnoyers de Biéville.

bibl.title: ‘A pretty piece of business', farce in one act by Thomas Morton the younger.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 October for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 1 November 1853. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘Family secrets, or, How to make home happy', farce in one act by W. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November for performance at the Lyceum 7 November 1853.

bibl.title: ‘A pet of the public', farce in one act by Edward Stirling.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November for performance at the Strand 7 November 1853. Request for licence written and signed by J. W. Allcroft. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘The hope of the family' ('Borrowed plumes'), comedy in three acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 November for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 19 November 1853. Revisions throughout. Different types of paper with additional text inserted throughout.

bibl.title: ‘Whitebait at Greenwich', farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 November for performance at the Adelphi 14 November 1853. Actors' names included in dramatis personae. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘A nice firm', farce in one act by 'John Roakes' (i.e., Tom Taylor).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 November for performance at the Lyceum 19 November 1853.

bibl.title: ‘The sailor of France, or, The republicans of Brest', drama in two acts by J. B. Johnstone, possibly in collaboration with J. Courtney.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 November for performance at the Surrey 28 November 1853.

bibl.title: ‘The thirst of gold, or, The lost ship and the wild flower of Mexico', drama in five tableaux, adapted from the French of d’Ennery and Dugué by B. N. Webster.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 November for performance at the Soho Theatre 5 December 1853. Title page signed with Paris address. Songs and diagrams included in MS. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records that the title was changed in 1874 to ‘The prayer in the storm’ or ‘The thirst, etc.’.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 13, no. 195 , and said to have been performed at the Adelphi under the title The sea of ice, or, The prayer of the wrecked and the gold-seeker of Mexico.

bibl.title: ‘A bachelor of arts', drama in two acts by Pelham Hardwicke.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 November for performance at the Lyceum 29 November 1853. Actors' names appear alongside dramatis personae.

bibl.title: ‘Once upon a time there were two kings', burlesque in two acts, founded on the story by the Countess d’Aulnoy La princesse Capillon, by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December for performance at the Lyceum 26 December 1853. Songs are printed and included at back.

bibl.title: ‘Eustache‘, drama in three acts by John Courtney.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 January 1854 for performance at the Surrey. Songs included in MS.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 15, no. 224, as Eustache Baudin.

bibl.title: ‘Ranelagh', comic drama in two acts by J. P. Simpson and Cecil Wray.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 February for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 9 February 1853. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘A good run for it', farce in one act by J. V. Bridgeman.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 February for performance at Sadlers Wells 13 February 1854. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that the word 'damn' be omitted as well as one other phrase.

bibl.title: ‘Away with melancholy', farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 March for performance at the Princess’ 13 March 1854. Stage directions and speaking cues underlined in red. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Number one, round the corner', farce in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 March for performance at the Lyceum 9 March 1854. Signed by G. Hastings, copyist, 2 Grafton L. East, Fitzroy Square. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that 'Oh Lord!' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The married unmarried', drama in two acts by Morris Barnett.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 13 March for performance at the Princess’ 25 March 1854.

bibl.title: ‘Ben Bolt', drama in two acts by J. B. Johnstone.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 March for performance at the Surrey Theatre 28 March 1854. Request for licence written and signed by stage manager. Signed by Messrs. Shepherd and Creswick, lessees. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted. Elaborate stage directions. Songs included in MS. For another version see Add. 52947 A.

bibl.title: ‘The moustache movement', farce in one act by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 March for performance at the Adelphi 30 March 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Last few pages on different paper and in a different hand.

bibl.title: ‘Mr Buckstone's voyage round the globe (in Leicester Square)', an extravaganza in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 10 April for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 17 April 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Jos. Hastings for J. B. Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘The overland journey to Constantinople as undertaken by Lord Bateman with interesting particulars of the fair Sophia', burlesque in two acts, by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 April for performance at the Adelphi 17 April 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions throughout. Diagrams and songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Heads or tails', comedietta in one act, by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 April 1854 for performance at the Olympic.

bibl.title: ‘The marble heart, or, The sculptor's dream', drama in five acts by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 May for performance at the Adelphi 18 May 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the phrase 'Eve before the apple season' be omitted. For a French version under the title Filles de marbre see Add. 52946 R.

bibl.title: ‘From village to court', a petit comedy in two acts by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 June for performance at the Princess’s 5 June 1854.

bibl.title: ‘The courier of Lyons' ('The Lyons mail' al. 'The courier of Lyons, or, The attack upon the mail'), romantic drama in three acts by Charles Reade, translated and adapted from the play by L. I. E. Lemoine-Moreau, E. de Girardin, and A. C. Lartigue.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 June for performance at the Princess’s, 26 June 1854. 'Mr Kean consented to certain omissions from the MS as suggested by the Examiner of Plays' written on title page in a hand that appears to be that of W. B. Donne. Passages are marked in pencil. For other versions see Add. 52948 P, 52948 S and 52951 T.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 15, no. 220, as The courier of Lyons, or, The attack upon the mail.

bibl.title: ‘The Lowther Arcade, or, Waiting for an omnibus on a rainy day', farce in one act by C. W. S. Brooks.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 June for performance at the Adelphi 28 June 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Revisions throughout.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 15, no. 215, where it is attributed to J. M. Morton.

bibl.title: ‘As like as two peas', farce in one act by Hubert Lille.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 June for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 30 June 1854. Signed 'with Mr. Buckstone's compliments'. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that the word 'damn' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The old chateau, or, A night of peril', drama in three acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 July for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 24 July 1854. Actors’ names listed alongside dramatis personae. 'Examiner abroad for 7 days' noted on title page. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘Living too fast, or, A twelvemonth's honeymoon', farce in one act by Adolphus C. Troughton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 July for performance at the Princess’ 9 October 1854.

bibl.title: ‘My friend the major', farce in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 September for performance at the St.James’s 25 September 1854. Signed by Laura Seymour. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The avalanche, or, The trials of the heart', drama in four acts by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 September for performance at the Surrey 3 March 1854. Additional stage directions added in pencil, and there are revisions where parts of the page have been entirely removed.

bibl.title: ‘A blighted being', farce in one act by 'John Roakes' (i.e., Tom Taylor).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 October for performance at the Olympic 16 October 1854. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths as well as the words 'Lord' and 'God' be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Bona fide travellers, a romance of the new Beer Bill', dramatic sketch in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 October for performance at the Adelphi 30 October 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster.

bibl.title: ‘The miser of Shoreditch', drama in two acts by T. P. Prest.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 October for performance at the Standard 2 November 1854. Signed by John Douglass.

bibl.title: ‘The slow man' ('The quiet man'), farce in one act by Mark Lemon.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 November for performance at the Adelphi 16 November 1854. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Some revisions.

bibl.title: ‘The railway belle', farce in one act by Mark Lemon.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 November for performance at the Adelphi 20 November 1854. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘The balance of comfort', farce in one act by W. B. Bernard.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 November for performance at 21 November 1854. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone. Actors' names listed alonside dramatis personae.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 17, no. 241; see also another play under the same title with the alternative title ‘To marry or not to marry’, attributed to R. J. Raymond, published in Duncombe’s, vol. 31, no. 248.

bibl.title: ‘A comical countess', farce in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 November for performance at the Lyceum 27 November 1854. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The wife's journal' ('My wife's diary'), comedietta in one act by T. W. Robertson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 December for performance at the Olympic 18 December 1854.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's as My wife's diary, vol. 18, no 257.

bibl.title: ‘Abou Hassan, or, The hunt after happiness', semi-original fairy tale in rhyme in one act by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 December for performance at the St.James’s 26 December 1854. Signed by Laura Seymour. Signed by J. G. Saunders, copyist, 41 Church Road, Commercial Rd East, 1854.

bibl.title: ‘Two heads are better than one' ('The false head; or, The haunted house'), farce in one act by F. Lennox Horne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 December for performance at the Lyceum 13 December 1854. Corrections pasted in.

bibl.title: ‘Harlequin and Bluebeard the Grand Bashaw, or The good fairy triumphant over the genius of discord', pantomime.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 December 1854 for performance at the Surrey. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 contains extensive entry that requires some of the comic business to be omitted. Not listed in Nicoll.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 17, no. 245, with ‘great’ and ‘demon’ substituted for ‘grand’ and ‘genius’ in the title, and there said to have been produced at the Princess’s Theatre on 26 December 1854.

keywords.term: fairies and other the supernatural creatures

bibl.title: ‘The yellow dwarf' ('The yellow dwarf, and the king of the gold mines'), an extravaganza in one act.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December for performance at the Olympic 26 December 1854. Songs included in MS in a different hand and ink as though added in later. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that the following couplet be omitted: 'And so your suit it's idle to be urging / I'll go down to my grave a Blessed Virgin'.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 17, no. 245, where it is attributed to J. R. Planché.

bibl.title: ‘Tit for tat', comedietta in two acts by F. Talfourd and A. S. Wigan.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 10 January for performance at the Olympic 22 January 1855. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘Too much of a good thing', farce in one act by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 February for performance at the Lyceum 6 February 1855.

bibl.title: ‘Clarisse, or, The foster sister', drama in two acts translated and adapted by T. W. Robertson, from the French of MM D’Ennery and Clement.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 February for performance at the St. James’s 17 February 1855. Signed by A. Sanger, acting manager. Also performed in English as ‘Ernestine’, at the Princess’s Theatre, and as ‘Noémie’ and ‘The foster sister’, at the Grecian Saloon.

bibl.title: ‘Take that girl away!', farce in two acts by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 March for performance at the Lyceum 3 March 1855.

bibl.title: ‘The secret agent', comedy in two acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 March for performance at the Haymarket 5 March 1855. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone. Revisions throughout. Some revisions pasted in. Several different types of paper used.

bibl.title: ‘A game of romps', farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 March for performance at the Princess’s 12 March 1855.

bibl.title: ‘Betty Martin' ('The clockmaker's hat'), farce in one act by T. W. Robertson, based on ‘Le chapeau d’un horologer’ by Mme. Emile de Girardin.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 March for performance at the Adelphi 12 March 1855. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster. Later performed at the St.James’s 3 July 1865.

bibl.title: ‘A cosy couple', drama in one act, by ‘Slingsby Lawrence’ (i.e. G. H. Lewes).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 March for performance at the Lyceum 14 March 1855. This script not listed in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘The muleteer of Toledo', drama in two acts by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 March for performance at the Princess’s 9 April 1855. Written on several different types of paper. Stage directions and speaking cues underlined in red. Songs included in MS. For another version, see Add. 52959 P.

bibl.title: ‘The new (Hay-) market spring meeting', extravaganza in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 March for performance at the Haymarket 9 April 1855. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Still waters', drama in three acts by 'John Roakes' [i.e., Tom Taylor].
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 April for performance at the Olympic 14 May 1855.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 22, no. 319, under the title ‘Still waters run deep’.

bibl.title: ‘Only a halfpenny', farce in one act by John Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 May for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 31 May 1855. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Helping hands', domestic drama in two acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 June for performance at the Adelphi 20 June 1855. Request for licence written and signed by Benjamin Webster.

bibl.title: ‘Buckstone's adventure with a Polish princess', original farce in one act by 'Slingsby Lawrence, Esq.' [i.e. G. H. Lewes].
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 June 1855 for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 4 July 1855. 'G. H. Lewes, 7 Clarence Row, East Sheen, Surrey' appears on title page. Some revisions.

bibl.title: ‘How stout you're getting', farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 July for performance at the Princess’s 16 July 1855.

bibl.title: ‘Faust and Marguarite' [sic], a musical burletta in one act by James Tully and John Halford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 August for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 16 August 1855. Signed by James H. Tully and Joseph Stammers.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 73, where it is attributed to Halford alone, and is said to have been produced on 8 June 1854.

bibl.title: ‘How's your uncle, or, The ladies of the court', farce in one act by T. E. Wilks.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 August for performance at the Adelphi 27 August 1855. Request for licence written and signed by B. Webster.

bibl.title: ‘The man of many friends', comedy in three acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 August for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 1 September 1855. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone. Songs included in MS. Revisions throughout. Written by several different hands and on several different papers.

bibl.title: ‘The little treasure', comedy in two acts by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 October for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 11 October 1855. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone. LCO Day Book Add. 53703 records the stipulation that several lines be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Catching a mermaid', an ‘amphibious piece of extravagance’ by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 October for performance at the Royal Olympic 20 October 1855. Revisions throughout.

bibl.title: ‘The beginning and the end', drama in four acts by 'Miss Maria Lacy' [i.e. Mrs. G. W. Lovell].
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 October for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 27 October 1855. Request for licence written and signed by J. B. Buckstone.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Cumberland’s, vol. 47, no. 393, and according to Nicoll, also in Lacy's, but this reference has not been verified.

bibl.title: ‘£5 Reward!', farce in one act by John Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 November for performance at the Olympic 3 December 1855.

bibl.title: ‘Blow in the dark,' farce in one act by W. Thompson Townsend.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 December for performance at the Surrey 3 December 1855.

bibl.title: ‘The great gun trick, or, Half an hour with the original Lyceum wizard', farce in one act by Christian Le Ross.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 31 December 1855. Signed ‘E.T. Smith, T. R. D. Lane’ on back cover.

bibl.title: ‘The discreet princess, or, The three glass distaffs', extravaganza in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December for performance at the Olympic 26 December 1855. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Jessy Vere, or, The return of the wanderer’, farce in one act by C. H. Hazlewood.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 January for performance at the Britannia Saloon February 1856. Signed Samuel Lane, proprietor.

bibl.title: ‘The victor vanquished’, comedy in one act by Charles Dance.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 January for performance at the Princess’s. Also performed in 1845.

bibl.title: ‘The married flirt, or, A conjugal lesson’ (‘Stay at home’), comedy in two acts by Henry Danvers.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 January for performance at the Olympic 3 July 1856. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted. For another version, see Add. 52960 A.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s (as A conjugal lesson), vol. 27, no. 392.

bibl.title: ‘That blessed baby’, farce in one act by F. Moore.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 February for performance at the Adelphi 11 February 1856. Request for licence signed Benj. Webster. According to Nicoll,
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, but the reference has not been verified.

bibl.title: ‘A prince for an hour’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 March for performance at the Princess’s 24 March 1856. Stage directions and speaking cues underlined in red.

bibl.title: ‘The evil genius’, comedy in three acts by W. B. Bernard.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 March for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 8 March 1856. Request for licence signed J. B. Buckstone.

bibl.title: ‘Tafelhausen, or, The legend of a lawyer’, drama in two acts by J. B. Johnstone.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 March for performance at the Surrey 24 March 1856. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that the words ‘Lord’ and ‘Oh Lord’ be omitted. Two different types of paper used. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Retribution’, domestic drama in four acts by Tom Taylor, based on Le loi de talion by Charles de Bernard.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 March for performance at the Olympic 12 May 1856. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 53073.

bibl.title: ‘A fascinating individual, or, Too agreeable by half’, farce in one act by Henry Danvers.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 April for performance at the Olympic 9 June 1856. Letter signed by ‘Mr. J. Linden for Mr. A. Wigan’ bound into MS.

bibl.title: ‘Sarah’s young man’, farce in one act by William E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 April for performance at the Surrey 21 April 1856. Cover signed Messrs. Shepherd and Creswick.

bibl.title: ‘The rights of woman’, farce in one act, by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 May for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 24 May 1856.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 26, no. 385, under the title The rights and wrongs of woman.

bibl.title: ‘A conjugal lesson’, farce in one act by Henry Danvers.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 June 1856 for performance at the Olympic 3 July 1856. Letter requesting licence signed by W. J. Emden bound in with MS.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 27, no. 392. For another version, see Add. 52958 P.

bibl.title: ‘Music hath charms’, farce in one act by David Fisher.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 June for performance at the Princess 7 July 1856. Speaking cues and stage directions are underlined in red.

bibl.title: ‘Medea, or, The best of mothers with a brute of a husband’, burlesque in one act by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 July for performance at the Olympic 14 July 1856. Revisions in different coloured inks throughout the text. Signed Rob. B. Brough, 4 South Lambeth Place, Vauxhall on back cover. Songs included in MS. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that two lines referring to Sir Charles Eastlake to be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Second love’, original comic drama in three acts by G. W. Simms and J. Bradshaw.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 July for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 23 July 1856. Request for licence signed by J. B. Buckstone. Written in Buckstone and Webster’s copyist’s hand. Signed G. W. Simms and J. Bradshaw on back cover. Songs included in MS. Incorrectly bound together with Add. 52960 P. Attributed in Nicoll to J. P. Simpson.

bibl.title: ‘The half caste’, drama in four acts by T. W. Robertson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 August 1856 for performance at the Surrey 8 September 1856. Cover signed Suter. Revisions throughout. Elaborate stage directions.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 97, no. 441, as The half caste, or, The poisoned pearl. See also Add. 52961 R, another version with the title ‘The taint in the blood, or, The poisoned pearl’.

bibl.title: ‘Perditta, the royal milkmaid, or, The winter’s tale’, burlesque in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 September 1856 for performance at the Lyceum 15 September 1856. Cover signed Charles Dillon, actual and responsible manager. Songs included in MS and written in a different hand.

bibl.title: ‘I’ll write to the Times’, farce in one act by J. P. Wooler.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 October 1856 for performance at Sadlers Wells 16 October 1856.

bibl.title: ‘Dred, or, The great dismal swamp’, drama in two acts by William E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 November for performance at the Queen’s October 1856. Cover signed C. J. James. See also Add. 52961 N, 52961 P, 52962 G, 52962 H, and 52962 U.

bibl.title: ‘A border marriage’, comic drama in one act by W. J. Sorrell.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November 1856 for performance at the Adelphi 3 November 1856. Request for licence signed Benj. Webster. Actors’ names included alongside dramatis personae. ‘J.M. Langford and W. J. Jonell, 43 Denbigh Street, Belgrave Road’. Revisions throughout text. Different types of paper used, and some sheets are stamped, ‘Commercial Travellers Magazine’. Diagrams included.

bibl.title: ‘A family failing’, farce in one act by J. Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket 17 November 1856. Request for licence signed by J.B. Buckstone. Title page signed John Oxenford with address.

bibl.title: ‘Doing the hansom’, farce in one act by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 November for performance at the Lyceum 3 November 1856. Request for licence signed Charles Dillon.

bibl.title: ‘Harlequin Aladdin, or, The wonderful lamp’, pantomime.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 December for performance at the Princess’s. Stage directions and speaking cues are underlined in red or black. Attributed in Nicoll to J. M. Morton under the title ‘Aladdin and the wonderful lamp’ with a performance date of 25 December.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s under the title Aladdin and the wonderful lamp, vol. 29, no. 422.

bibl.title: ‘Conrad and Medora, or, Harlequin Little Fairy at bottom of the sea’, pantomime by William Brough, based on the ballet ‘Le corsaire’.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December for performance at the Lyceum 26 December 1856. Songs included in MS.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 29, no. 423, with the alternative title Harlequin Corsair and the Little Fairy at the bottom of the sea.

bibl.title: ‘Young and handsome’, a fairy extravaganza by J. R. Planché, from the fairy tale ‘Jeune et belle’, by Madame Murat.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December for performance at the Olympic 26 December 1856. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Crinoline’, farce in one act by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 December for performance at the Olympic 18 December 1856. Cover signed Robert B. Brough. Revisions throughout text. Speaking cues and stage directions underlined in contrasting ink.

bibl.title: ‘A night at Notting Hill', farcical sketch in one act by N. H. Harrington and E. Yates.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 January for performance at the Adelphi 5 January 1857. Request for licence signed Benjamin Webster. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Ruth Oakley', drama in three acts by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 January for performance at the Marylebone 15 January 1857.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 29, no. 431. Attributed in Nicoll jointly to Harris and T. J. Williams.

bibl.title: ‘A splendid investment', an original farce in one act by W. B. Bernard.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 April for performance at the Olympic 11 February 1857.

bibl.title: ‘Double faced people', comedy in three acts by John Courtney.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 April for performance at the Haymarket 7 February 1857. Intended performance date given as 7 February 1857. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted as well as the name of Lord Palmerston. Some revisions to text.

bibl.title: ‘A life's ransom', drama in five acts.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 March for performance at the Lyceum 16 February 1857. Cover signed by the lessee, Charles Dillon. Revisions to text added on different types of paper.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 54, no. 804, where it is attributed to Westland Marston.

bibl.title: ‘A wicked wife', comedy in one act by John Courtney.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 March for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 16 February 1857. Some revisions to text.

bibl.title: ‘The marble bride, or, Nymphs of the forrest', magical drama in two acts by C. H. Hazlewood.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 March 1857 for performance at the Britannia Saloon that month.

bibl.title: ‘A sheep in wolf's clothing', domestic drama in two acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 March for performance at the Olympic 19 February 1857. Revisions throughout the text.

bibl.title: ‘My friend from Leatherhead', farce in one act by N. H. Harrington and E. Yates.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 April for performance at the Lyceum 23 February 1857.

bibl.title: ‘The victims of fraud' ('Fraud and its victims'), drama in a prologue and four acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 April for performance at the Surrey 2 March 1857. Intended performance date listed on cover is 2 March 1857. 'J. Stirling Coyne, 2 Wilmington Square' written on cover. Revisions throughout the text.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's as Fraud and its victims, vol. 29, no. 433.

bibl.title: ‘Angel or devil', drama in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 April for performance at the Lyceum 2 March 1857. Intended date of performance is listed on cover as 2 March 1857.

bibl.title: ‘A life's trial', drama in four acts by W. B. Bernard.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 April for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 19 March 1857. Intended performance date listed on cover is 19 March 1857. Revisions throughout the text.

bibl.title: ‘Atalanta, or, The three golden apples', burletta in one act by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 April for performance at the Haymarket 13 April 1857. Space left for songs to be inserted later.

bibl.title: ‘An Englishman's house is his castle', farce in once act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 April for performance at the Princess’s, 11 May 1857. Stage directions and speaking cues underlined in red.

bibl.title: ‘Fearful tragedy in the Seven Dials', farce in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 April for performance at the Adelphi 4 May 1857. Request for licence signed Benjamin Webster. See Add. 52966 Z.

bibl.title: ‘My son Diana', farce in one act by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 May for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 25 May 1857.

bibl.title: ‘The husband of an hour', drama in two acts by Edmund Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 May for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 30 May 1857.

bibl.title: ‘Masaniello', an extravaganza in one act by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 June for performance at the Olympic 2 July 1857. Many revisions in different hands and on different types of paper. Illustration of revolutionaries’ banners included on p. 65. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that a phrase mentioning the Prince of Wales be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Victims', original comedy in three acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 July for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 8 July 1857. Each act appears to have been posted separately. Actors’ names included alongside dramatis personae.

bibl.title: ‘What will they say at Brompton?', farce in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 August for performance at the Olympic 23 November 1857. Cover signed Stirling Coyne but crossed out. Actors' names listed alongside dramatis personae. Revisions throughout text. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that a large number of political allusions be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘An unequal match', comedy in three acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 September for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 3 October 1857. Revisions or prompter’s notes throughout text in different hands and different coloured inks.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 118. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 53073.

bibl.title: ‘Up in the world', farce in one act by J. Worthington.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 October for performance at the Surrey the same day. Last page signed Messrs. Shepherd and Creswick. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A very serious affair', farce in one act by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 October for performance at the Lyceum 5 October 1857. Written in the hand of the copyist employed by Benjamin Webster and J. B. Buckstone. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Leading strings', comedy in three acts by A. C. Troughton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 October for performance at the Olympic 19 October 1857. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Take care of Dowb—’, a farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 November for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 23 November 1857. Revisions throughout the text.

bibl.title: ‘The doge of Duralto, or, The enchanted eyes', Christmas extravaganza by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December for performance at the Olympic 26 December 1857. Many revisions and stage cues added in different hands, sometimes in pencil. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Harlequin novelty, and the princess who lost her heart', pantomime by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December for performance at the Strand 24 December 1857. ‘Leicester Buckingham, 14 Clements Inn’ written on cover. Comic scenes written on different paper to rest of text.

bibl.title: ‘Pierette, or, The rivals’, comic opera in one act by Edward Fitzball.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 December 1857 for performance at the Theatre Royal Hull 6 March 1858. Includes letter signed by the Examiner W. B. Donne stating that ‘the Opera “Pierette” (intended for representation at Hull) belongs to Mr. Montgomery of the Lyceum Theatre London to whom he requests any communication about it will be sent.’ Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘What will they say at Brompton?', farce in one act by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 August for performance at the Olympic 23 November 1857. Cover signed Stirling Coyne but crossed out. Actors' names listed alongside dramatis personae. Revisions throughout text. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that a large number of political allusions be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘An unequal match', comedy in three acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 September for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 3 October 1857. Revisions or prompter’s notes throughout text in different hands and different coloured inks.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 118. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 53073.

bibl.title: ‘Up in the world', farce in one act by J. Worthington.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 October for performance at the Surrey the same day. Last page signed Messrs. Shepherd and Creswick. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A very serious affair', farce in one act by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 October for performance at the Lyceum 5 October 1857. Written in the hand of the copyist employed by Benjamin Webster and J. B. Buckstone. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Leading strings', comedy in three acts by A. C. Troughton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 October for performance at the Olympic 19 October 1857. LCO Day Book Add. 53073 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Take care of Dowb—’, a farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 November for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket 23 November 1857. Revisions throughout the text.

bibl.title: ‘The doge of Duralto, or, Tthe enchanted eyes', Christmas extravaganza by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December for performance at the Olympic 26 December 1857. Many revisions and stage cues added in different hands, sometimes in pencil. Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘Harlequin novelty, and the princess who lost her heard', pantomime by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December for performance at the Strand 24 December 1857. ‘Leicester Buckingham, 14 Clements Inn’ written on cover. Comic scenes written on different paper to rest of text.

bibl.title: ‘Pierette, or, The rivals’, comic opera in one act by Edward Fitzball.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 December 1857 for performance at the Theatre Royal Hull 6 March 1858. Includes letter signed by the Examiner W. B. Donne stating that ‘the Opera “Pierette” (intended for representation at Hull) belongs to Mr. Montgomery of the Lyceum Theatre London to whom he requests any communication about it will be sent.’ Songs included in MS.

bibl.title: ‘A twice told tale’, original comedietta in one act by J. P. Wooler. (Described as a farce in Lacy’s.)
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 September 1858 for performance at the Olympic. Also published in Lacy’s, vol.37, no. 553.

bibl.title: Nothing to nurse, original farce in one act by Charles M. Walcot. Printed. Lacy’s edition, vol.33, no.485.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 September 1858 for performance at the Strand. Letter written on title page and signed by C. Swanborough suggests the theatre may have been accused of performing the play without a licence. Original first performance at Laura Keene’s Theatre, New York, September 1857.

bibl.title: ‘My aunt’s husband’, original farce in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 September 1858 for performance at the Strand. Also

bibl.title: ‘I’ve written to Browne’ (altered from‘A needless stratagem'), farce in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 January 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Letter from M. E. Conway to the Examiner regarding the title change bound in with front cover. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 lists it as a comedietta.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 40, no. 595. Texts vary slightly between MS and printed version.

bibl.title: ‘The young mother’, drama in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 February for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket on 28 February 1859.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 39, no. 574. The Lacy’s version contains variations from the MS text and more detailed stage directions.

bibl.title: ‘If the cap fits’, farce in one act by N. H. Harrington and E. Yates.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 February 1859 for performance at the Princess‘s. Nicoll cites the date 13 June 1859.

bibl.title: ‘The world and the stage’, comedy in three acts by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 March to be performed 12 March 1859 at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that the words ‘Oh Lord’ and all other oaths be omitted.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 97, no. 1444. Lacy’s edition contains more detailed stage directions.

bibl.title: ‘Vandyke Brown’, farce in one act by A. C. Troughton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 March 1859 for performance at the Strand. Copied by G. Hastings. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that a section of text be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Everybody’s friend’ (‘The widow hunt'), comedy in five acts by J. S. Coyne.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 March for performance at the Haymarket on 2 April 1859. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted. MS contains extensive cuts in ink and pasted-in amendments.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 40, no. 586. Later performed at the St.James’s, October 1867 as ‘The widow hunt’ (see Nicoll), and subsequently published in De Witt’s Acting Plays, no. 12.

bibl.title: ‘Nine points of the law’, comedietta in one act by T. Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 April 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Contains numerous cuts and amendments made both in ink and pencil.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 40, no. 600. Based on the novel Clover Cottage, or, I can’t get in, by M. W. Savage, 1856.

bibl.title: ‘Beau Brummel’ (‘Beau Brummel, the King of Calais'), drama in two acts by M. W. B. Jerrold.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 April for performance at the Lyceum on 10 April 1859. MS written in more than one hand.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 44, no. 652 as Beau Brummel, the King of Calais. Various textual differences between Lacy’s and MS versions.

bibl.title: ‘Electra in a new electric light’, classical extravaganza in one act by F. Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 April 1859 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 39, no. 585. Lacy’s contains more detailed stage directions and titles of popular songs.

bibl.title: ‘Ruthven’, drama in three acts by A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 April 1859 for performance at the Grecian Saloon. Contains words to song.

bibl.title: ‘Which of the two!’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 April 1859 for performance at the Strand. Signed by the copyists E. and J. Hastings.

bibl.title: ‘Ici on parle Francais’, farce in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 May 1859 for performance at the Adelphi.

bibl.title: ‘Retained for the defence’, farce in one act by J. Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 13 May 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Cuts and amendments made in pencil. List of actors’ names next to the dramatis personae.

bibl.title: ‘The member‘s wife, or, The house versus the home’, comedy in two acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 13 May 1859 for performance at the Adelphi. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation to ‘omit all oaths and the name of Mr Brotherton’.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 42, no. 618, as The house or the home; adapted from Peril dans la demeure, by Octave Feuillet.

bibl.title: ‘A felon’s bond’, drama in three acts by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 May 1859 for performance at the Grecian Saloon.

bibl.title: ‘Caught by the ears’, farcical extravaganza in one act by C. Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 May 1859 for performance at the Strand. Copied by G. Hastings.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 41, no.604. Lacy’s edition includes musical excerpts for piano and voices.

bibl.title: ‘Payable on demand’, domestic drama in two acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 June 1859 for performance at the Olympic. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that biblical references be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘Give me my wife’, farce in one act by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 June 1859 for performance at the Grecian Saloon. Signed W. E. Suter. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The rifle volunteers’ (‘The rifle volunteers, or, Riflemen! Riflemen! Riflemen! Form!'), an 'apropos sketch' in one act by Edward Stirling.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 13 June 1859 for performance at the Adelphi. Listed in Nicoll, with the alternative title, as a farce. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 52703.

bibl.title: ‘The masked mother, or, The hidden hand’ (‘Capitola, or, ‘The masked mother and the hidden hand’), drama in two acts by C. H. Hazlewood.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 1 July to be performed on 4 July 1859 at the Surrey. Letter from the Licensor stating that ‘a copyist for this play will be sent to the L.C. office on Monday next.‘ Cuts made to text in ink. Cut-outs from a printed periodical version pasted in and edited. Signed by the copyist, Adelaide Calvert. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 70, no. 1047. Considerable variation between the MS and Lacy’s versions. Based on the novel The hidden hand, or, Capitola the madcap, by E. D. E. N. Southworth, (New York, 1859).

bibl.title: ‘A school for coquettes’, comedietta in two acts by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 July to be performed on 9 July 1859 at the Strand.

bibl.title: ‘The lady of Lyons’,‘the very latest extravaganza by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 July 1859 for performance at the Strand. Signed E. and J. Hastings, copyists. For another version, see Add. 52971 K.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s , supplementary volume, no volume or index reference. A later, revised version of the Lacy’s edition is cited in Add. 52971 K. For the original The lady of Lyons, or, Love and pride! by Lord Lytton, which was licensed in 1838, see Add. 42945 (11).

bibl.title: ‘Cartouche, or, The six escapes of a robber’, drama in three acts by W. Travers.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 July 1859 for performance at the City of London Theatre.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 76, no. 1031. Considerable variation between the MS and Lacy’s versions.

bibl.title: ‘An old offender’, comic drama in two acts by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 July 1859 for performance at the Adelphi.

bibl.title: Prison and palace, comic drama in two acts by J. Palgrave Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 August 1859 for performance at the Canterbury.
bibl.pubNote: Printed for private circulation in an edition of Lacy’s. Back cover signed Hon. S.(?) Ponsonby. First performed at Thurloe Place West, Brompton, February, 1853. Russian settings, military, prison, prisoners, flirtation, police, royalty, Petersburg, dance, politics, engagements.

bibl.title: ‘The goose with the golden eggs’, farce in one act by A. Mayhew and H. S. Edwards.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 August 1859 for performance at the Strand.

bibl.title: ‘The rifle and how to use it’, farce in one act by J. V. Bridgeman.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 September 1859 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket.

bibl.title: ‘Love and fortune’, dramatic tableau in one act by J. R. Planché.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 September 1859 for performance at the Princess’s on 24 September 1859. Inside cover signed Augustus Harris. Contains words for songs and some pencilled-in stage directions.

bibl.title: ‘Love and hunger’, farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 26 September 1859 for performance at the Adelphi.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 42, no. 624. Differences between Lacy’s text and MS text.

bibl.title: ‘Virginius, or, The trials of a fond father’, burlesque in one act by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 September for performance at the St.James’s on 1 October 1859. Copied in more than one hand. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: ‘The magic toys’, ballet farce in one act by J. Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 September 1859 for performance at the St.James’s. Signed J. Oxenford on front cover. ‘Miss L. Thompson’ pencilled next to list of dramatis personae. Set design inside front cover in ink.

bibl.title: ‘A husband to order’, farce in two acts by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 October 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Some amendments in ink. Adapted from the French play, ‘Un mariage sous l’Empire’.

bibl.title: ‘The fool’s revenge’, tragedy in three acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 October 1859 for performance at Sadlers Wells on 18 October 1859. Prompt copy written in more than one hand, containing various additional stage directions in ink and pencil. Influenced by Le roi s’amuse by Victor Hugo, published in 1832, and Verdi’s Rigoletto, 1851: see Tom Taylor’s introduction to the Lacy’s edition.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 43, no. 631. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that‘Heaven' be substituted for 'God'.

bibl.title: ‘The head of the family’ comedietta in one act by W. S. Emden.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 October 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Adapted from ‘Le moulin a paroles’.

bibl.title: ‘Romeo and Juliet, or, The cup of cold pison’ (sic), extravaganza in one act by Andrew Halliday. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that a substantial amount of text be omitted. Published in Lacy’s, vol. 43, no. 633. Keywords: literary references, poison, popular song, Italian characters and settings, Verona, doctors, photography, dreams, ballet, masquerade, nurses, animals, monks, operatic references, murder, politics, games, family relationships, narcotics, dance, ghosts.
‘The master passion, or, The outlaws of the Adriatic’ (‘Outlaws of the Adriatic, or, The female spy and the chief of the ten’), drama in three acts, (possibly) by Edmund Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 November 1859 for performance at the Princess’s.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 673. Adapted from the French play by Victor Sejour.

bibl.title: ‘Dinorah under difficulties’, farcical sketch in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 November 1859 for performance at the Adelphi.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 81, no. 1226, in a considerably expanded text. For other versions of the story, see Add. 52984 F, 52985 A, and 52992 C.

bibl.title: ‘The dead heart’, drama in three acts and a prologue by Watts Phillips.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 November 1859 for performance at the Adelphi.

bibl.title: ‘Nursey Chickweed’, farce in one act by Thomas J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 November 1859 for performance at the Princess’s.

bibl.title: ‘Paris and pleasure! or, Home and happiness’,‘drama fantastique' in four acts by C. Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 November for performance at the Lyceum on 28 November 1859. Signed Celeste Elliott, sole lessee. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that the theatre licensee should 'superintend the production of the first act'.

bibl.title: ‘Gossip’, comedy in two acts by A. G. Harris and T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 November 1859 for performance at the Princess’s. Signed A. Harris.

bibl.title: ‘Shameful behaviour’, comedietta in two acts by A. C. Troughton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 November 1859 for performance at the Strand. Contains words for a song.

bibl.title: ‘Alfred the Great’ (‘Alfred the Great, or, The minstrel king’), extravaganza in one act by R. B. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 December 1859 for performance at the Olympic. Various cuts in ink. Contains words for song.

bibl.title: ‘Tell and the strike of the Cantons, or, The pair, the meddlar and the apple’, extravaganza by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December 1859 for performance at the Strand. MS written in more than one hand.

bibl.title: ‘The nymph of the Lurleyberg, or, The knight and the naiads’ (altered from ‘Lurline’), extravaganza in one act by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1859 for performance at the Adelphi. For other versions of the story, see Add. 52990 C, 52990 M, and 53011 K.

bibl.title: ‘Jack the giant killer, or, Harlequin King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table’, pantomime by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 December 1859 for performance at the Princess’s . Comic scenes bound within MS.

bibl.title: ‘King Thrushbeard, or, Pet and passion’ (sic) (‘King Thrushbeard, or, The little pet and the great passion'), burlesque by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 December 1859 for performance at the Lyceum. Listed in Nicoll and Lacy’s under the longer alternative title.

bibl.title: ‘The household fairy’, domestic sketch in one act by Francis Talfourd.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 December 1859 for performance at the St.James’s. Stage directions written in red ink and underlined in black. Back page signed Francis Talfourd Esquire.

bibl.title: ‘The Christmas box system’, farce in one act by A. Mayhew and H. S. Edwards.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 January 1860 for performance at the Strand. Cuts made in pencil.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 46, no. 685 as Christmas boxes.

bibl.title: ‘A tale of two cities’, drama with prologue and two acts by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 January 1860 for performance at the Lyceum. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that the word‘Heaven' be substituted for 'God'. Based on the serialisation published in All the year round, April – November 1859, by Charles Dickens.

bibl.title: ‘A day at Boulogne, or, Run to earth’, farce in one act by Marshall Hall.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 February 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Brighton. Title pasted over the original title.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Run to earth, or, A day at Boulogne in Lacy’s, supplementary vol. 2.

bibl.title: ‘Dido’, burlesque by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 January 1860 for performance at the St. James’s. Contains words for songs and detailed stage directions.

bibl.title: ‘The forest keeper’, drama in two acts by Henry Holl.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 February 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. MS written in more than one hand. Cover signed E. J. Smith.

bibl.title: ‘Sisterly service’, comedietta in one act by J. P. Wooler.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 February 1860 for performance at the Strand. Text bears inscription‘H. Chater, scripsit'. MS written in more than one hand. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘First affections’, comedietta in one act by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 February 1860 for performance at the St.James’s. Extensive cuts and amendments made in ink.

bibl.title: ‘Holly Bush Hall’, drama in two acts by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 February for performance at the Queen’s on 25 February 1860. Cover signed C. J. James. MS bears name of W. E. Suter. Cited in Nicoll as ‘Holly Bush Hall, or, The track in the snow’. For other versions, see Add. 52989 M and 52989 S.

bibl.title: ‘A play of disasters, or, Next of kin’, farce in one act by Edmund Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 February 1860 for performance at Theatre Royal, Birmingham. Text bears name of E. H. Keating. Postage stamps affixed to back cover.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 46, no. 679 under the title Next of kin. Later produced at the Lyceum 9 April 1860, for which version see Add. 52991 T.

bibl.title: ‘Uncle Zachary’, in two acts by John Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 February 1860 for performance at the Olympic.

bibl.title: ‘Cruel to be kind’, farce in one act by T. J. Williams and A. G. Harris.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 March 1860 for performance at the Princess’s. MS written in more than one hand. Inside cover bears name of A. Harris.

bibl.title: ‘Christmas Eve, or, A duel in the snow’ (altered from‘The wife’s prediction'), domestic drama in three acts by Edward Fitzball.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 March 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Text bears name of E. T. Smith. Nicoll cites a further production under the title ‘A duel in the snow’, at Sadlers Wells on 4 June 1862.

bibl.title: ‘B. B., or, The Benicia Boy’, farce in one act by F. C. Burnand and M. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 March 1860 for performance at the Olympic. The script is based on the famous boxing match between Tom Sayers and the American John Heenan, known as‘the Benicia Boy' which took place on 17 April 1860. For other version, see Add. 52992 L, 52993 B and 52993 D.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 668. Keywords inns, Northumberland, press, boxing, waiters, servants, landladies, rail travel, mistaken identity, dining, engagement.

bibl.title: ‘117 Arundel Street, Strand’ (altered from‘Batchelors lodgings' (sic) and 'Honi soit qui mal y pense'), comedietta in one act by H. R. Addison.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 March 1860 for performance at the Lyceum. Numerous cuts and amendments made in ink. The original title 'Batchelors lodging' has the description 'a domestic sketch borrowed from our neighbours’, crossed out in ink.

bibl.title: ‘Lucretia Borgia, at home and all abroad’, burlesque in one act by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 April 1860 for performance at the St.James’s. Stage directions underlined in red ink.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 672 as Lucrezia Borgia! At home and all abroad.

bibl.title: ‘Next of kin’, comedietta in two acts by E. Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 April for performance at the Lyceum 9 April 1860. Contains calls, scene changes and cuts in ink, stage directions in pencil. A previous version of the play was produced at Birmingham, for which see Add. 52990 F.

bibl.title: ‘The pilgrim of love’, extravaganza (‘an oriental fairy tale in rhyme') in one act by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 April 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket. MS signed by the author, f. 78. Additions, cuts, cues and stage directions in pencil and ink. Extra page added for Finale. Actors’ names written in pencil next to the dramatis personae. Contains words for songs. Based on Washington Irving’s novel Tales of the Alhambra (originally published 1832).
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 671, as The pilgrim of love, a fairy romance in one act.

bibl.title: ‘The miller and his men’, extravaganza in one act by F. Talfourd and H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 April 1860 for performance at the Strand. Stage directions and cues underlined in red ink. Contains words to songs.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 670, where it is described as‘a burlesque mealy-drama in one act (and in verse)'.

bibl.title: ‘A change of system’, petite comedy in one act by Howard Paul.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 April 1860 for performance at the St.James’s.

bibl.title: ‘The sylphide’, extravaganza in one act by William Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 April 1860 for performance at the Princess’s. Contains words for songs.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 76, no. 1040, and in supplementary vol. no. 2.

bibl.title: ‘A race for a widow’, comedietta in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 18 April 1860 for performance at the Strand. Stage directions underlined in red ink.

bibl.title: ‘A friend in need’, comedy in two acts by Sydney J. G. French and William Sorrell.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 20 April 1860 for performance at the St.James’s. Inside cover bears the name of a‘Miss Wyndham' written in ink.

keywords.term: north of England/south of England contrasts

bibl.title: ‘Dearest Mamma, or, My mother-in-law', comedietta in one act by 'Walter Gordon' (i.e., William Aylmer Gowing).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 May 1860 for performance at the Olympic. Contains cuts in ink. Adapted from the French play, 'La belle-mére et le gendre" by J. I. Samson, 1826.

bibl.title: ‘The family secret', comedy in three acts by E. Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 May 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket.

bibl.title: ‘Tromb-al-ca-zar, or, Les criminels dramatiques', operetta in one act by C. Dupeuty and E. Bourget (for the music by J. Offenbach).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 May 1860 for performance at the Lyceum. French. First performed at the Bouffes Parisiens, Paris, 3 April 1856. Not listed in Nicoll.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Tromb-Al-Ca-Zar; or The adventures of an orphan troupe by C. H. Stephenson in Lacy’s, vol. 71, no. 1053. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: Thrice married (A personation piece), farce in one act by H. M. Paul.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 May 1860 for performance at the Princess‘s. Printed, possibly the Lacy’s edition.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 45, no. 665, as A personation piece. This is an English version of the play La femme aux oeufs d’or, by MM. Dumanoir and Clairville (i.e. P. F. Pinel and L. F. Nicolaie), for which see Add. 52992 Z.

bibl.title: ‘Fitz-Smythe of Fitz-Smythe Hall' (altered from 'Jollyboy of Jollyboy Hall'), farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 May 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket. Signed J. M. Morton (with address). Original title is crossed out in ink on opening page and throughout play; cuts made in ink, numbered cues in pencil.

bibl.title: ‘Appearances', comedy in two acts by J. P. Simpson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 May 1860 for performance at the Strand.

bibl.title: Furnished apartment, vaudeville in one act by‘MM. Cormon et Grangé' (i.e., P. E. Piestre and Eugène Basté). Printed. French.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 June 1860 for performance at the St James’s. First performed at the Variétés, Paris, 7 June 1855. Printed by Michel Lèvy Frères in Bibliotheque Dramatique Series. Publisher’s advertisement on front and back covers. Not listed in Nicoll.
bibl.pubNote: Published under the title The French exhibition; or, Noodles in Paris by Frederick Hay in Lacy’s, vol. 75, no. 1117.

bibl.title: ‘Does he love me?', comedy in three acts by E. Falconer.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 June 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket. Signed Thos. Pugh (?). MS copied in more than one hand, numbered cues and amendments in pencil.
