bibl.title: ‘Duchess or nothing', comedietta in one act by 'Walter Gordon' (i.e., William Aylmer Gowing).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 June 1860 for performance at the Olympic. Adapted from the French play, 'The Marquise de Carabas'.

bibl.title: ‘His Excellency', farce in one act by C. J. Mathews.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 July 1860 for performance at the Theatre Royal. Inside cover signed Thos. Pugh, under prompter.

bibl.title: ‘Bowl'd out', farce in one act by 'Henry Thornton Craven' (i.e., Henry Thornton).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 10 July 1860 for performance at the Princess's. MS written in two different hands.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 47, no. 694 as Bowl'd out, or, A bit of Brummagem.

bibl.title: ‘Observation and flirtation', comedietta in one act by Horace Wigan.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 25 July 1860 for performance at the Strand.

bibl.title: ‘A fair exchange' (altered from 'Exchange is no robbery'), farce in one scene by Montagu Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 August 1860 for performance at the Olympic. Stage directions in red ink, numbered cues in pencil, cuts in ink.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 47, no. 703. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: ‘The veteran and his son, or, France and Algeria' (altered from 'The daughter of the desert, or, The veteran and his son'), drama in three acts.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 September 1860 for performance at the Surrey. Acting copy, partly printed, with numerous MS additions in the shape of cuts in ink and pencil.
bibl.pubNote: Printed part taken from The veteran of 102 years, or five generations, by H. M. Milner’s, in Lacy’s, vol. 36, no. 534. The middle section of the script is also in MS. 'From Messrs. Shepherd and Creswick' (theatre managers) on front cover. Back page signed R. Shepherd. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths must be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘The pet lamb', comedietta in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 September 1860 for performance at the Strand. MS written in more than one hand, signed by the copyists, E and J Hastings, 9 University Street, Tottenham Court Road. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 52703.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 47, no. 702. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: ‘Hit him he has no friends', farce in one act by E. Yates and N. H. Harrington.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 September 1860 for performance at the Strand. Cues underlined in red ink. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation that all oaths be omitted.

bibl.title: ‘A decided fix', farce in one act by J. M. Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 17 September 1860 for performance at the Olympic.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 48, no. 714 as A regular fix!

bibl.title: ‘The Gitanella, or, The children of the forest', drama in three acts by J. Crawford Wilson.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 September 1860 for performance at the Surrey.
bibl.pubNote: Published as The Gitanilla; or, The children of the Zincali in Lacy’s, vol. 48, no. 713. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: ‘Robin Hood, or, The merry outlaws of Sherwood', equestrian spectacle in three acts by Edward Fitzball.

bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 48, no. 718. For another version, see Add. 52995 Q. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: ‘John Wapps, or, From information I received', farce in one act by W. E. Suter.

bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 49, no. 724 as John Wopps, or, From information I received.

bibl.title: ‘Up at the hills', comedy in two acts by Tom Taylor.

bibl.title: ‘Post boy', petite drama in two acts by H. T. Craven (i.e. Henry Thornton).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 October 1860 for performance at the Strand. Decorative calligraphy on title page in black and red ink with small illustration in black ink of the post boy, signed H. Chater Scripsit (see also Add. 52990 N).

bibl.title: ‘Home for a holiday', comedietta in one act by Walter Gordon (i.e. William Aylmer Gowing). MS indicates ‘from the French’, source untraced.

bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 49, no. 722. Contains words for songs.

bibl.title: Une tasse de thé, comedy in one act by Ch. Nuitter and J. Derley. Printed. French.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 November 1860. First performed at the Vaudeville, Paris, 28 September 1860. Publisher’s catalogue attached (Michel Lévy, Paris, August 1860). Publisher’s advertisement on back cover. Not listed in Nicoll or LCO Day Book Add. 52703.
bibl.pubNote: Published as A cup of tea in Lacy’s, vol. 83, no. 1254.

bibl.title: ‘The Garibaldi excursionists', sketch in one act by H. J. Byron.

bibl.title: ‘The babes in the wood', comedy in three acts by Tom Taylor.

bibl.title: ‘Did I dream it?', (alternative title from ‘Charming dreams’), farce in one act by J. P. Wooler.

bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy’s, vol. 50, no. 739. Contains words to songs.

bibl.title: Eclipsing the son, farce in one act by W. W. Hartopp. Printed. Lacy‘s edition.

bibl.pubNote: Published as Peter Wilkins, or, Harlequin and the flying women of the Loadstone Rock, by E. L. Blanchard., The MusicPublishing Company, London. See also Add. 52970 D. Earlier variant Peter Wilkins; or, The flying islanders published by Lacy’s, vol. 25, no. 374.

This MS copy appears to have been used as an exhibit in a court case concerning the play, the following statement being written on the front cover, "In Chancery. Elliott v. Cave. This is the exhibit marked 1 referred to in the Affidavit of Rophino Lacy sworn in this Cause the day of April 1861 Before me". See also Add 53002 J, Add. 53002 Q and Add. 53003 N, for other versions.

bibl.title: ‘The Cantab', farce in one act by T. W. Robertson.

bibl.title: ‘The chimney corner', serio-comic drama in two acts by H. T. Craven.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 February 1861 for performance at the Olympic.

bibl.title: ‘Only a scrap of paper', comedy in three acts by J. P. Simpson.

bibl.title: ‘House on the bridge of Notre Dame', drama in two acts by C. H. Hazlewood.

bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1862, no theatre indicated. Identifies C. Dumerie, copyist, 22 Mornington Place, Hampstead Rd. Amendments and cues in pencil.

bibl.title: ‘George de Barnwell, or, Harlequin folly in the realms of fancy', burlesque pantomime by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1862 for performance at the Adelphi. Indicates Mr B. Webster, manager. MS written in more than one hand. Numerous cuts, paste-ins and amendments in ink. Cues in pencil.

bibl.title: ‘Rasselas, Prince of Abyssinia', burlesque by W. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1862 for performance at the Haymarket. MS written in more than one hand. Numerous cues in pencil. Appears unfinished. Scene six appended.

bibl.title: ‘Robin Hood, or, the foresters fête', extravaganza in one act by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 December 1862 for performance at the Olympic. Initial and final scenes re-foliated in red pencil. Paste-ins and additions in ink. MS written in more than one hand.

bibl.title: ‘Ivanhoe', burlesque by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 December 1862 for performance at the Strand. Listed as ‘Ivanhoe in accordance with the spirit of the Times’ in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘The Duke’s Motto', prologue and drama in three acts by J. Brougham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 December 1862 for performance at the Lyceum. Also indicates licensed by Lord Chamberlain 3 January 1863. MS in more than one hand. Paste-ins, cues and additions in pencil. Dramatis personæ in pencil on ff. 2, v. Indicates name and address of C. Fechter on ff. 84, v. Listed in Nicoll as 'The Duke’s Daughter; or, the Hunchback of Paris' and later as 'The Duke’s Crest'.
bibl.pubNote: Published without attribution in Lacy’s, vol. 57, no. 852. See Add. 53022 A, Add. 53024 C and Add. 53024 B.

bibl.title: ‘The dark cloud', drama in two acts by G. Rose.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 January 1863, no details of theatre. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 52703. Attributed to Arthur Sketchley (i.e. George Rose) in Nicoll for performance at St.James's.

bibl.title: ‘First floor, second floor and attics; or, Up and down', farce in one act by John Maddison Morton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 January 1863 for performance at the Princess's. Unattributed in Nicoll.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Drawing Rooms, Second Floors and Attics in Lacy's, vol. 62, no. 925.

bibl.title: ‘The merry widow', comedy in two acts by Leicester S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 February 1863 for performance at the St.James's. Identifies Leicester Buckingham on cover of each act. Amendments and cuts in pencil. LCO Daybook Add. 52703 records date of licence as 5 February 1863.

bibl.title: ‘A faint heart which did win a fair lady', farce in one act by J. P. Wooler.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 February 1863 for performance at Strand.

bibl.title: ‘A valentine, a compliment of the season', in one act by W. Brough and A. Halliday, (i.e. A. H. Duff).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 February 1863 for performance at the Adelphi. Identifies Mr B. Webster. Nicoll attributes to W. Brough and A. Halliday.
bibl.pubNote: Published as A Valentine ! in Lacy's, vol. 57, no. 844.

bibl.title: ‘My preserver', farce in one act by H. Thornton.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 February 1863 for performance at Strand. Attributed to H. T. Craven (i.e. H. Thornton) in Nicoll. Partial wax seal on back cover.

bibl.title: ‘Lady Audley's Secret', drama in two acts by W. E. Suter. No details of
bibl.licence: Licence date for performance at Queen’s. Adapted from the novel Lady Audley’s Secret by Mary Elizabeth Braddon, London 1862. Note signed C. J. James indicating intended first performance 21 February 1863. Signed W. E. Suter at the end of each act. Act number on cover amended from three to two in ink. Autograph script. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 17 February 1863.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 57, no. 849. See Add. 53020 I, Add. 53022 W and Add. 53028 S.

bibl.title: ‘Taming the truant', comedy in three acts by Horace Wigan.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 16 March 1863 for performance at the Olympic. MS written in more than one hand. Cast list on title page. Nicoll lists play as an adaptation of Victorien Sardou's 'Le Papillon' (sic), Sardou's 'La Papillionne', first performed at the Theatre-français, 11 April 1862.

bibl.title: ‘Aurora Floyd; or, The deed in the wood', drama in two acts by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 29 March 1863 for performance at the Queen’s. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 30 March 1863. Autograph copy. Signed C. J. James. Stage positions indicated at end of play.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 58, no. 856. See Add. 53020 O, Add. 53021 A, Add. 53022 G and Add. 53022 H.

bibl.title: ‘The thirty-nine thieves', burlesque. No details of licence for performance at the Strand. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 31 March 1863. Unattributed in Nicoll. Attributed to Henry J. Byron and published as Ali Baba; or, The Thirty-Nine Thieves. In Accordance with the Author's Habit of Taking One off! in Lacy's, vol. 59, no. 882.
‘The trial of Tompkins', farce in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 March 1863 for performance at Adelphi. Identifies Mr B. Webster, manager. Listed as 'The Trials of Tompkins' in Nicoll.
bibl.pubNote: Published as The Trials of Tompkins ! in Lacy's, vol., 58, no. 859.

bibl.title: ‘Acis and Galatea', extravaganza in one act by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 March 1863 for performance at the Olympic. Names of actors listed in pencil next to dramatis personæ. Cues in pencil throughout. Cuts in ink. MS written in more than one hand. Listed as 'Acis and Galatea; or, The Nimble Nymph and the Terrible Troglodyte' in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘Mr. Buckstone at home; or, the manager and his friends', extravaganza by J. S. Coyne. No details of licence sent for performance at the Haymarket. MS written in more than one hand. Ammendments and paste-ins made in blue ink. Cues and stage directions in pencil. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 4 April 1863. Published as Buckstone at home; or, The manager and his Friends in Lacy's, vol. 58, no. 857.
‘Beautiful Haidée', burlesque in one act by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 April 1863 for performance at the Princess's. Stage cues in pencil and ink.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's. vol. 58, no. 857 as Beautiful Haidée; or, The Sea Nymph and the Sallee Rovers. "Founded on the poem of Don Juan, the ballad of Lord Bateman, and the legend of Lurline".

bibl.title: ‘The little sentinel!', comedietta in one act by Thomas J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 2 May 1863 for performance at the St.James's. Not listed in LCO Day Book Add. 52703.

bibl.title: ‘Lady Audley’s Secret', drama in two acts by C. H. Hazlewood.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 May 1863, no details of theatre. Stamped "Frederick Frampton and Fenton" on title page. Penny red on front cover. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records place of performance as the Victoria.
bibl.pubNote: Published by Lacy's, but not in Lacy's List. Appears in Supplementary Vol. II of collection lodged at the British Library.

bibl.title: ‘The ticket of leave', drama in three acts and a prologue by Tom Taylor. No date of licence sent for May 1863 performance at the Olympic. MS in more than one hand. Corrections in ink. Cues in pencil and several actors’ names written opposite script. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 27 May 1863. Listed in Nicoll as 'The Ticket-of-Leave Man'. Published in Lacy's, vol. 59, no. 871 as The Ticket-of Leave Man. A drama in four acts. Founded on a French dramatic tale Le Retour de Melun, included in Les Drames de la Vie by MM. Brisbarre and Nuz, Paris, 1860. See Add. 53017 P, Add. 53024 A and Add. 53023 O.
‘Ill-treated Il Trovatore', burlesque in one act by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 27 May 1863 for performance at the Adelphi. Identifies Mr B. Webster.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Ill-treated Il Trovatore; or, The Mother, The Maiden, and The Musicianer in Lacy's, vol. 58, no. 866.

bibl.title: ‘Court and camp', drama in three acts by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 May 1863 for performance at the Princess's. MS written in more than one hand. Translated from the original by M. Paul Meurice, first performed at the Ambigu-Comique 1858. Listed in Nicoll under title 'Fan-Fan, the Tulip; or, Soldier’s Fortune'. Title of 'Court and Camp' for the performance at the Princess's, at the Britannia as 'Days of Louis XV' and under the title of 'The King’s Butterfly' at the Lyceum. See Add. 53026 D.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Fan-Fan, the Tulip; or, Soldier’s Fortune in Lacy's, vol. 65, no. 974.

bibl.title: ‘Cousin Tom', comedietta in one act by G. Roberts.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 6 June 1863 for performance at the Princess's. Attributed to George Roberts in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘First Love; or, The widowed bride', drama in three acts by W. E. Suter. No details of licence for performance at the Grecian. Autograph copy. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 11 June 1863. Published in Lacy's, vol. 69, no. 1033.
‘Easy shaving!', farce in one act by F. C. Burnand and M. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 June 1863, no details of place of performance. Prompt copy. Cues and cuts in pencil and ink. Actor’s names in pencil next to dramatis personæ. MS written in more than one hand. Identifies M. Montague Williams on title page. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records title without exclamation mark.

bibl.title: ‘The motto: I’m all there', burlesque by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 July 1863 for performance at the Strand.
bibl.pubNote: Published in Lacy's, vol. 59, no. 875. See Add. 53024 C, Add. 53018 AA and Add. 53022A.

bibl.title: ‘Turn him out', farce in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 August 1863 for performance at the Strand. MS written in more than one hand.

bibl.title: Simply an advertisment, farce in one act.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 8 August 1863 for performance at the Assembly Rooms, Herne Bay.
bibl.pubNote: Printed by Lacy but does not appear in Lacy‘s List of Acting Editions. Identifies William Watson, manager. Acting copy, amended in pencil and ink. Unattributed in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘The pirates of Putney', nautical extravaganza in one act by Charles Selby.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 August 1863 for performance at the Royalty. Paste-ins. Stage cues in ink.

bibl.title: ‘The highwayman’s holiday', farce in one act by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 September 1863 for performance at the Queen's. Signed C. J. James, lessee and manager. Autograph copy. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 6 September 1863.

bibl.title: ‘Ixion; or, The man at the wheel', extravaganza by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 15 September 1863 for performance at the New Royalty. Stage directions and characters underlined in red ink. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 14 September 1863.

bibl.title: ‘The deal boatman', drama in two acts by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 September 1863 for performance at Drury Lane. Corrections and cues added in ink. Not listed in the LCO Day Book Add. 52703. Nicoll incorrectly lists this title as 'The Boatman of Deal' in the Lord Chamberlain's collection.
bibl.pubNote: Published as The Deal Boatman, a serio-comic drama in Lacy's, vol. 60, no. 889.

bibl.title: ‘Where’s your wife?', comedietta in one act by J. V. Bridgeman.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 September 1863 for performance at the Strand.

bibl.title: ‘Leah', drama in five acts by A. Daly.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 28 September 1863 for performance at the Adelphi. Identifies Mr B. Webster. Original genre of tragedy crossed out in ink on front cover. Listed as 'Leah the Forsaken' in Nicoll. First performed at the Howard Athenæum, Boston, 8 December 1862.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Leah, the Forsaken in Lacy's, vol. 97, no. 1454.

bibl.title: ‘The days of Louis the fifteenth; or, Fanfan the tulip and the camp at Caen, the mill at Laufield, and the Royal Gardens', drama in two acts by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 September 1863 for performance at the Britannia. Identifies Samuel Lane, proprietor. 'and the mill at Laufield, and the royal gardens' added in ink to the original title on front cover of each act. Minor corrections in ink in different hand. Unlisted in Nicoll. Relicensed version of Add. 53023 C.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Fan-Fan, the Tulip; or, Soldier's Fortune in Lacy's, vol. 65, no. 974.

bibl.title: ‘Miriam's crime', domestic drama in three acts by H. T. Craven (i.e. Henry Thornton).
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 October 1863 for performance at the Strand.

bibl.title: ‘Beauty or the beast?', farce in one act by J. Oxenford.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 31 October 1863 for performance at Drury Lane. Actor's names in ink next to dramatis personæ on title page. Cuts and notes in ink. Cues in pencil.

bibl.title: ‘Pure gold', drama in four acts by J. W. Marston.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 4 November 1863 for performance at Sadler's Wells. MS written in more than one hand. Corrections and additions in ink in second hand. Identifies Rob. Edgar, lessee and manager. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 5 November 1863.

bibl.title: ‘Blanche de Nevers', opera in four acts.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 5 November 1863 for performance at Covent Garden. Identifies W. Harrison, manager. "Opera in three acts" on title page. MS written in more than one hand. Numerous cuts and additional notes in second hand. Paste-ins, music cues and songs numbered. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 31 October 1863. Attributed as 'Blanche of Nevers; or, I am here' to W. S. Hyde, performed in Manchester on 6 April 1863 in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘Little Daisy', comedietta in one act by T. J. Williams.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 7 November 1863 for performance at the Haymarket. MS in more than one hand. Stage directions and speakers underlined in red ink.

bibl.title: ‘My heart's in the highlands', (altered from 'My hearts in the highlands'), farce in one act by W. Brough and Andrew Halliday.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 9 November 1863 for performance at Drury Lane. Actor's names in ink next to dramatis personæ on title page. Minor corrections in ink.

bibl.title: ‘The waiter at the Eagle', farce in one act by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 12 November 1863 for performance at the Grecian. Signed W. E. Suter on back cover. Signed B. Conquest, actual and responsible manager. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the stipulation to omit the lines " Gracious! My fathers wife dreadful woman that ought to have been my mother! Horrible! And I was about to commit a dreadful tragedy was about to make [illegible] father oh awful!" Nicoll cites this as an alternative title to 'The Waiter at Cremorne' of 1855, which does not appear to be in the LCP's collection and is not listed in the LCO Day Book Add. 52703.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Our New Man in Lacy's, vol. 65, no. 967.

bibl.title: ‘Silken fetters', comedy in three acts by L. S. Buckingham.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 14 November 1863 for performance at the Haymarket. MS in more than one hand. Speakers and stage directions underlined in red ink in first act.

bibl.title: ‘Patient Penelope; or, The return of Ulysses', burlesque by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 23 November 1863 for performance at the Strand. Actor's names in ink next to dramatis personæ on title page. Attributed to F. C. Burnand and M. Williams in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘Mad as a hatter', farce in one act by F. Marshall.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 3 December 1863 for performance at the Royalty.

bibl.title: ‘Stolen - £20 reward', farce in one act by W. Hancock.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 11 December 1863 for performance at the Royalty. Lists W. Hancock as author of 'John Smith' on front cover. Not listed in Nicoll.

bibl.title: ‘The lost child! ; or, A father in search of his child', (altered from 'A Father in Search of His Child'), farce in one act by W. E. Suter.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 19 December 1863 for performance at the Lyceum. Cuts in ink. Numerous cues and notes on stage positions in pencil. Final page and title in different hand. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 does not records number of acts.
bibl.pubNote: Published as The Lost Child in Lacy's, vol. 62, no. 922.

bibl.title: ‘Orpheus and Eurydice', extravaganza by Henry J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 21 December 1863 for performance at the Strand. "Classical burlesque extravaganza" on front cover. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records the date of licence as 19 December 1863.
bibl.pubNote: Published as Orpheus and Eurydice; or, The Young Gentleman Who Charmed the Rocks in Lacy's, vol. 61, no. 908.

bibl.title: ‘Lady Belle Belle; or, Fortunio and his seven magic servants', pantomime by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1863 for performance at the Adelphi. Identifies Mr B. Webster. "Comic fairy tale" on title page.

bibl.title: ‘King Arthur; or, The days and knights of the round table', pantomime by W. Brough.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 22 December 1863, no details of theatre. MS in more than one hand. Actor's names in ink next to the dramatis personæ on title page. Promptcopy. Cues in pencil. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records place of performance as the Haymarket.

bibl.title: ‘1863; or, The sensations of the past season with a comical revelation of Lady Somebody's Secret', pantomime by H. J. Byron.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 December 1863 for performance at the St. James's. Pages inserted. Corrections in ink. Adephi theatre crossed out in ink on front cover.

bibl.title: ‘Madame Berliot's ball; or, The chalet in the valley', comedietta in one act by F. C. Burnand.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 24 December 1863 for performance at the Royalty. Actor's names in ink next to dramatis personæ on title page.

bibl.title: ‘Sense and sensation; or, The seven sisters of Thule', a Christmas morality by Tom Taylor.
bibl.licence: Licence sent 30 December 1863 for performance at the Olympic. MS written in more than one hand. Promptcopy. Cues and notes in pencil. Cuts and corrections in ink. Notes on front cover crossed out in ink. LCO Day Book Add. 52703 records date of licence as 29 December 1863. Nicoll cites performance for 16 May 1864.
